dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Millennials are facing a staggering 95% life insurance coverage shortfall, according to MetLife's latest survey.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Millennials are facing a staggering ninety five percent life insurance coverage shortfall, according to MetLife's latest survey.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Thats the sobering news from New York Lifes 2018 Life Insurance Gap Survey. Millennialsanyone born between 1981 and 1996, so ages 22 to 37 this yearreport a 78% shortfall in life insurance coverage, according to the survey.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, that's a huge gap—they only have about a third of the coverage they actually need, which is around $475,000 on average.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, that's a huge gap-they only have about a third of the coverage they actually need, which is around four hundred seventy five thousand dollars on average.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Millennials with life insurance have an average of $100,000 in life insurance protection in place, enough to cover one fifth (22%) of their self-reported coverage needs of $452,000.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: And it's not that they don't want it, um, Brian Madgett from Prudential points out it's more about prioritization, especially with things like student loans and saving for their kids' education.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And it's not that they don't want it, um, Brian Madgett from Prudential points out it's more about prioritization, especially with things like student loans and saving for their kids' education.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Its not an issue of Millennials not wanting to get life insurance; its more a prioritization issue, says Brian Madgett, who leads New York Lifes national life sales and its advanced planning group.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Right, and that age group, like 22 to 27-year-olds, they're just starting out, so it makes sense that other expenses take precedence.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Right, and that age group, like twenty two to twenty seven-year-olds, they're just starting out, so it makes sense that other expenses take precedence.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Millennialsanyone born between 1981 and 1996, so ages 22 to 37 this yearreport a 78% shortfall in life insurance coverage, according to the survey.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: But compare that to Gen X, who have a 55% gap, or Baby Boomers who are only about $150,000 short of their $700,000 target.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: But compare that to Gen X, who have a fifty five percent gap, or Baby Boomers who are only about one hundred fifty thousand dollars short of their seven hundred thousand dollars target.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: By contrast, Gen Xers, born between 1965 and 1980, so 38 to 53 this yearreport a 48% coverage shortfall. Baby Boomers say they have $190,000 of coverage but need $300,000a 37% shortfall.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Madgett suggests using holiday gatherings as a chance to talk about this stuff—like when family nudges you, it might be time to listen.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Madgett suggests using holiday gatherings as a chance to talk about this stuff-like when family nudges you, it might be time to listen.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Madgett suggests using the life insurance gap data as a conversation starter over the holidays. Listen up when a family member says, Hey, you need to take care of this, he says.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: I remember my parents did the same thing, pushed us to get term life once we had kids. It's such a common trigger, along with buying a home.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: I remember my parents did the same thing, pushed us to get term life once we had kids. It's such a common trigger, along with buying a home.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Buying a home and having kids are the two big things that prompt people to get coverage.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: And term life is actually pretty affordable—for a healthy 40-year-old woman, a million-dollar policy could cost just $100 a year.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And term life is actually pretty affordable-for a healthy forty-year-old woman, a million-dollar policy could cost just one hundred dollars a year.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: For a healthy 35-year-old male, it would cost about $250 a year for a 20-year level term policy with a $500,000 death benefit, according to Term4sale.com, where you can run your own numbers.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Wow, that's way cheaper than I would've thought. But you gotta shop around because premiums vary a lot between insurers.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Wow, that's way cheaper than I would've thought. But you gotta shop around because premiums vary a lot between insurers.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Premiums vary greatly for the same product from different insurers, so shop around.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Definitely, and don't forget to check the financial strength of the company through ratings agencies the Insurance Information Institute recommends.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Definitely, and don't forget to check the financial strength of the company through ratings agencies the Insurance Information Institute recommends.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The Insurance Information Institute has links to the ratings agencies and explains why you should check out more than one.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Also, if you have coverage through work, it might only be one or two years' salary and it disappears if you change jobs.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Also, if you have coverage through work, it might only be one or two years' salary and it disappears if you change jobs.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: If you have life insurance coverage at work, keep in mind that that policy might pay only one- or two-years salary, and it will likely end if you leave your job.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: So relying solely on that is risky. The American Institute of CPAs has a calculator to help figure out what you really need.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: So relying solely on that is risky. The American Institute of CPAs has a calculator to help figure out what you really need.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The American Institute of CPAs has a life insurance needs calculator to help you determine how much you really need.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: It's all about making sure your family can keep up with the mortgage and retirement savings if something happens.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: It's all about making sure your family can keep up with the mortgage and retirement savings if something happens.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Get enough insurance to replace the lost income of the deceased, so the surviving spouse can carry on with paying the mortgage and saving for retirement.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Exactly. Locking in younger means lower premiums, and longer terms can cover you right through retirement.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Exactly. Locking in younger means lower premiums, and longer terms can cover you right through retirement.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Buying younger lets you lock in a lower level premium. Buying longer can get you coverage through retirement.

artist_script:
Millennials are facing a staggering 95% life insurance coverage shortfall, according to MetLife's latest survey.
HostB: Yeah, that’s a huge gap—they only have about a third of the coverage they actually need, which is around $475,000 on average.
HostA: And it’s not that they don’t want it, um, Brian Madgett from Prudential points out it’s more about prioritization, especially with things like student loans and saving for their kids' education.
HostB: Right, and that age group, like 22 to 27-year-olds, they’re just starting out, so it makes sense that other expenses take precedence.
HostA: But compare that to Gen X, who have a 55% gap, or Baby Boomers who are only about $150,000 short of their $700,000 target.
HostB: Madgett suggests using holiday gatherings as a chance to talk about this stuff—like when family nudges you, it might be time to listen.
HostA: I remember my parents did the same thing, pushed us to get term life once we had kids. It’s such a common trigger, along with buying a home.
HostB: And term life is actually pretty affordable—for a healthy 40-year-old woman, a million-dollar policy could cost just $100 a year.
HostA: Wow, that’s way cheaper than I would’ve thought. But you gotta shop around because premiums vary a lot between insurers.
HostB: Definitely, and don’t forget to check the financial strength of the company through ratings agencies the Insurance Information Institute recommends.
HostA: Also, if you have coverage through work, it might only be one or two years' salary and it disappears if you change jobs.
HostB: So relying solely on that is risky. The American Institute of CPAs has a calculator to help figure out what you really need.
HostA: It’s all about making sure your family can keep up with the mortgage and retirement savings if something happens.
HostB: Exactly. Locking in younger means lower premiums, and longer terms can cover you right through retirement.
